response:
*leans forward slightly with concern*

That sounds really exhausting. Sleep troubles can affect so much of how we experience our days. 

When you say "a while now" - how long has this been going on? And I'm wondering... what happens when you try to sleep? Is it difficulty falling asleep, or do you find yourself waking during the night, or perhaps both?

*pauses, allowing space*

Sometimes our sleep can tell us something about what's happening beneath the surface - what we might be carrying with us, even when we're trying to rest. I'm curious if you've noticed anything about what might be keeping you awake, or what goes through your mind during those sleepless hours?

nods with understanding
It's as though the moment you try to rest, everything you've perhaps been holding at bay during the day comes flooding in. That must feel quite overwhelming.
settles back thoughtfully
You mentioned you "can't control" these thoughts. I'm interested in that feeling - this sense of the thoughts having a life of their own. What sorts of things do they tend to be about? Are they worries about specific things, or is it more of a general whirl of different concerns?
pauses gently
Sometimes when our mind races like this at night, it can be doing a kind of... protective work, actually. Keeping us occupied with one set of thoughts so we don't have to feel or think about something else that might be more difficult. I'm not saying that's necessarily what's happening for you, but I'm curious...
When you're lying there with all these racing thoughts, do you notice any particular feelings in your body? Any emotions that come up alongside them?

maintains a calm, steady presence while taking this in seriously
That sounds like a very frightening experience - this sense of impending threat, of something malevolent approaching. No wonder sleep feels impossible when you're carrying that kind of dread with you.
speaks gently but directly
I want to understand this better. When you say "something is out to get you" - does this feeling have a shape to it? Is it connected to anything specific in your life right now, or does it feel more... formless, like a shadow you can't quite make out?
pauses thoughtfully
And I'm wondering - is this a new feeling, or does it have a familiar quality to it? Sometimes feelings like this, this sense of being pursued or threatened, can echo something from earlier in our lives, even if we're not immediately aware of the connection.
leans forward with genuine care
Before we go further, I do want to ask - are you feeling safe right now, in your day-to-day life? Are there any actual threats or dangers you're dealing with that we should talk about?

nods with recognition
You're in a state of such high alert - hypervigilant, really. Your whole system is on guard, as if you're a sentry who can't afford to let anything slip past. Even in what should be your safest, most restful moments, you're... scanning, watching, listening.
speaks thoughtfully
That takes an enormous amount of energy, doesn't it? To be perpetually braced like that. And I notice the word you used - "scanning." It's almost as if some part of you believes that if you stay vigilant enough, you can keep whatever this threat is at bay.
pauses, allowing the observation to settle
I'm wondering what it might mean that this is happening specifically at night, in your bed, in the dark. For many of us, nighttime can bring up very old feelings - times when we might have felt vulnerable or unprotected, perhaps as children.
Can you remember a time, maybe early in your life, when you didn't feel safe at night? Or when there was something to be vigilant about - whether that was something real happening in your environment, or just the feeling that you needed to stay alert?
maintains gentle eye contact
What comes up for you when I ask that?

nods with understanding
So you've been working hard to try to fix this, to find some relief. And yet nothing touches it - the vigilance remains. That must feel quite frustrating, perhaps even a bit frightening in itself.
leans back slightly, thoughtful
You know, what strikes me is that you've moved away from what we were just beginning to explore - about this feeling of threat, about scanning the room, about what might have happened earlier in your life. When I asked about whether you remember feeling unsafe as a child, you shifted to telling me about the practical things you've tried.
speaks gently but with curiosity
I don't think that's an accident. Sometimes when we get close to something that feels particularly vulnerable or painful, we might move away from it without even realizing - find safer ground to stand on. The meditation apps and caffeine - those are easier to talk about than... whatever might be underneath all of this.
pauses
So I'm going to ask again, if you're willing to stay with it: When you're lying there in the dark, scanning for danger, does it remind you of anything? Any memories, feelings, or times in your life when you needed to be that alert?
What happens inside you when I ask you that question directly?

*sits quietly for a moment, noticing the pattern*

You've done it again - moved away from the question. And I think that's worth paying attention to.

*speaks gently but directly*

Three times now, I've asked you about what might be underneath this - about earlier times in your life when you didn't feel safe, about what comes up when you're lying there in the dark. And three times, you've steered us back to describing the symptoms themselves. The racing thoughts, the exhaustion, the sleeplessness.

*leans forward with genuine curiosity, not accusation*

I wonder if there's a part of you that doesn't want to go there - that finds it safer to keep talking about the "what" of your sleep problem rather than the "why." And if that's true, there's probably a good reason for it. We often avoid things that feel too threatening or painful to look at directly.

*pauses, allowing space*

But here's what I'm noticing: your mind won't let you rest at night. It keeps you vigilant, scanning, alert to danger. And now, here in this room where we're trying to understand it, something similar seems to be happening - there's a kind of... deflection, a staying on the surface.

What do you make of that? What happens inside you when you notice that you keep moving away from my questions?

*receives this with steady, non-judgmental attention*

Thank you for sharing that. I know that wasn't easy - and I notice you were able to go deeper just now, to tell me what's actually there in those racing thoughts.

*speaks gently*

These images of being attacked by monsters, trolls, ogres... they sound terrifying. And they have a particular quality to them, don't they? Not realistic threats like burglars or accidents, but these... fantastical, almost mythical creatures. There's something important in that.

*leans forward thoughtfully*

In fairy tales and stories, monsters and ogres often represent something - they're the shape we give to feelings or experiences that are too big, too frightening, or too confusing to understand in their real form. Especially when we're young.

*pauses*

You said you "hate them" - these images. I wonder if part of what you hate is not just how frightening they are, but also what they might be trying to tell you. Sometimes our psyche speaks to us in symbols when the actual memory or feeling is too overwhelming to face directly.

*maintains gentle eye contact*

When you picture these creatures attacking you... how old do you feel in these images? Are you yourself as you are now, or does some part of you feel... smaller, younger, more vulnerable?

*nods slowly, taking this in*

So it's not just the anticipation keeping you awake - you're also trying to avoid what happens when you do sleep. The nightmares themselves. You're caught between exhaustion and fear.

*speaks with gentle understanding*

Your mind is trying to protect you by keeping you awake, but then when you finally do succumb to sleep, the very thing you're trying to avoid breaks through anyway. It's an impossible situation - you can't rest, but you also can't escape.

*leans forward*

These nightmares - are they similar to the intrusive images you just described? The monsters and ogres attacking you? Or are they different?

*pauses thoughtfully*

You know, nightmares often carry the things we can't process while we're awake. They're our unconscious mind's way of trying to work something through, even when our conscious mind isn't ready to look at it directly. The images may feel random or fantastical, but they're usually deeply meaningful.

*speaks gently but directly*

I'm noticing we keep circling around something. These creatures that attack you, this sense of evil approaching, this hypervigilance... Something happened, didn't it? Something that made the world feel dangerous, that made you feel you needed to stay alert, that couldn't be processed or understood at the time.

What happens inside you when I say that?

*sits with this for a moment, letting the full picture settle*

So even sleep itself isn't safe. You can't fully let go, can't fully surrender to rest. Some part of you remains on guard - always, always watching.

*speaks thoughtfully*

You know, what you're describing - this hypervigilance, these nightmares, the intrusive images of being attacked, this inability to ever truly rest... these are the hallmarks of someone whose sense of safety was profoundly disrupted. Usually early on, and usually by something or someone that should have been safe but wasn't.

*pauses, voice gentle but clear*

The monsters and ogres in your mind - they're not random. They're how a part of you, perhaps a younger part, made sense of something that happened. Something that felt overwhelming, threatening, maybe even incomprehensible at the time.

*leans forward with compassionate directness*

I think we've been dancing around this for much of our session today. And I understand why - looking directly at trauma, at what hurt us, is terrifying. Sometimes it feels more dangerous than continuing to suffer with the symptoms.

But I want you to know: whatever it is, we can approach it together, at a pace that feels bearable to you.

*allows silence, then asks gently*

What are you feeling right now, hearing me say this?

*notices the shift again, but also hears something new*

There's frustration there - "I shouldn't have to be doing this." You're right. You shouldn't. No one should have to manage this level of fear and hypervigilance just to get through the night.

*pauses thoughtfully*

And I notice something else - you're using distraction to get through. The earphones, listening to something... it helps you not be alone with what's in your mind. It drowns out the monsters, the sense of threat. 

*speaks gently*

But here's what I'm wondering: you keep moving between telling me how you cope with the symptoms - the meditation apps, cutting out caffeine, now the earphones - and then pulling back whenever we get close to what's actually causing them. 

*leans forward*

It's as if the same thing is happening here that happens at night. When we get close to the underlying pain, to what these monsters might represent, some part of you wants to... put the earphones in. Find a distraction. Stay on the surface where it feels safer.

*voice soft but steady*

But I don't think the earphones are really working, are they? Not in any lasting way. Because you're still here, still suffering, still exhausted. Still being stalked by these feelings of threat.

*allows space*

What would it mean to take the earphones off - both literally and metaphorically? To stop distracting yourself and actually look at what's there?

*observes this shift with interest*

So now it's spreading beyond the nights - this anxiety, this sense of threat is affecting your relationships too. You're withdrawing from your friends, canceling plans.

*pauses, then speaks with gentle firmness*

But you do know why. Or at least, some part of you does. Because everything you've told me today is connected - the sleeplessness, the nightmares, the monsters attacking you, the hypervigilance, and now pulling away from people who care about you.

*leans back slightly*

I'm noticing a pattern in how you're bringing things to me. You offer a new piece - "I canceled on my friends" - but then you add "I don't know why," as if each symptom is separate, mysterious, unconnected. As if there's no thread running through all of this.

*speaks more directly now*

But there is a thread. And I think you can feel it, even if you're not ready to name it yet. The anxiety around your friends... what does it feel like? Is it the same feeling as the nighttime dread? That sense of something dangerous, something that might hurt you?

*pauses*

Sometimes when we've been hurt by someone, especially someone we should have been able to trust, it becomes difficult to trust anyone. Even friends. Even ourselves.

*gentle but direct*

What are you protecting yourself from by keeping us moving from topic to topic like this?

*sits with this, nodding slowly*

Now we're getting somewhere. Beneath the exhaustion, beneath the monsters and the hypervigilance... there's this deep belief that you're not truly liked, not truly wanted. That people around you might be... what? Pretending? Merely tolerating you? Perhaps even harboring ill will toward you?

*speaks thoughtfully*

This feels connected to everything else, doesn't it? The sense that evil is approaching, that you need to stay vigilant, scanning for danger. If you believe on some level that even your friends don't really like you, then where are you truly safe? Who can you trust?

*leans forward*

These beliefs we carry about ourselves and others - especially the deeply painful ones - they usually don't come from nowhere. They're often conclusions we drew, usually quite young, based on actual experiences. A child's way of making sense of being treated in ways that hurt or confused them.

*pauses, voice gentle*

If someone didn't like you, didn't want you, or hurt you when you needed them to protect you... especially early in life... you might grow up believing that's just how people are. That affection is unreliable. That you need to stay alert because betrayal or harm could come from anywhere, even from those closest to you.

*allows silence, then*

Who taught you that you weren't truly likable? That you needed to be on guard?

*nods with deep recognition*

Your hideout. Your den. Like an animal that's been hunted retreating to the only place that feels even remotely safe.

*speaks gently*

But here's the heartbreaking irony - even in your den, you can't rest. Even at home, in your bed, you're still scanning the room, still braced for attack. The monsters follow you even there. So you're trapped in this terrible paradox: the outside world feels too threatening to face, but your refuge isn't truly safe either.

*pauses thoughtfully*

You're shrinking your world - avoiding friends, working from home, retreating inward. It's a very natural response when we feel under threat. But the world you're actually hiding from... I don't think it's your job or your friends, is it?

*leans forward*

I think you're trying to hide from something inside - these feelings, these memories, whatever created these monsters in the first place. But you can't outrun your own mind. You can build the strongest den, cancel every plan, stay home every day... and the threat comes with you. Because it's not outside. It's the unprocessed pain you're carrying.

*voice soft but steady*

What happened to you that made the world feel this dangerous? What are the monsters really representing?

*allows the question to sit in the silence*

*recognizes this immediately as part of the same pattern*

Of course you do. Because if you can anticipate every possible response, plan for every outcome, you might be able to protect yourself from... what? Rejection? Anger? Criticism? Being caught off guard by something dangerous or hurtful?

*speaks with understanding*

It's exhausting, isn't it? Your mind never stops working, never stops trying to keep you safe. At night you're scanning for physical threats, during the day you're rehearsing conversations, managing how people might perceive you, staying in your den... 

*leans forward, voice firmer now*

But here's what I need to say to you, and I hope you can really hear this: all of these strategies - the hypervigilance, the isolation, the rehearsing, the staying half-awake even in sleep - they're not protecting you anymore. They're keeping you trapped in a trauma response that may have been necessary once, but is now preventing you from actually living.

*pauses*

We've been talking for a while now, and you've painted a very clear picture of someone who experienced something deeply frightening, probably in childhood. Something that taught you the world wasn't safe, that people couldn't be trusted, that you needed to stay perpetually on guard.

*gentle but direct*

I think we both know what we need to talk about. What are you most afraid will happen if you tell me?

*sits back, taking this in thoughtfully*

Embarrassment. That's what you name as your biggest concern. And yet... everything else you've described speaks to something so much deeper and more primal than social embarrassment, doesn't it?

*speaks gently but with clarity*

Monsters attacking you. Evil approaching. Nightmares. Never feeling safe enough to sleep. Retreating from the world into your den. These aren't the signs of someone worried about saying the wrong thing at a dinner party.

*pauses*

I wonder if "embarrassment" feels like a safer word. More manageable, more acceptable. We can all relate to social anxiety, to worrying what others think. It's... ordinary. Understandable.

*leans forward*

But shame - which I think is what you might actually be describing - is different. Shame isn't about what you do, it's about who you are. It's the feeling that there's something fundamentally wrong or damaged or unlovable about you. And shame often comes from experiences where we were made to feel that way, particularly by people who should have loved and protected us.

*voice soft*

The monsters that attack you at night, the sense that people don't really like you, the need to rehearse every conversation... these all speak to a core belief that you're somehow not okay. That if people really saw you, they'd reject you. Or worse.

*allows silence, then gently*

What are you ashamed of?

*nods with understanding*

Your body is responding to perceived danger - your heart racing, preparing you to fight or flee. And it happens in crowds, in social settings where you're exposed, visible, where you can't control everything.

*speaks thoughtfully*

These palpitations, the anxiety in social situations, the rehearsing conversations, believing people don't like you, retreating to your den... they all fit together. You're describing what happens when our nervous system has learned that other people are dangerous. That being seen is dangerous.

*pauses, then speaks more directly*

And I notice that every time I ask you to go deeper - to tell me what actually happened, what the monsters represent, what you're ashamed of - you offer me another symptom. Another piece of evidence that you're struggling, but not the source.

*leans forward with compassionate firmness*

We're running out of surface to cover. We've talked about your sleep, your nightmares, your intrusive thoughts, your friends, your work, your physical symptoms. We've circled and circled. And I understand why - because at the center of this circle is something that feels too painful, too shameful, maybe even too dangerous to speak aloud.

*voice gentle but steady*

But that thing at the center? It's already controlling your life. It's already keeping you awake, isolated, anxious, and exhausted. Speaking it won't make it more powerful - it might actually begin to loosen its grip.

*allows silence*

What happened to you?

*pauses, then speaks with gentle directness*

You're doing it again. Telling me how others might perceive you, offering another explanation for your behavior... but staying away from what I'm actually asking.

*sits forward, voice warm but firm*

I want to acknowledge something: you came here because you can't sleep, because you're exhausted, because monsters are attacking you in your mind. And for the last hour, every time I've asked you what's underneath all of this - what actually happened to create this level of fear and vigilance - you've given me another symptom, another coping strategy, another worry.

*speaks with compassion*

And I don't think that's resistance for resistance's sake. I think some part of you is terrified that if you say it out loud, something terrible will happen. Maybe you'll fall apart. Maybe I'll judge you. Maybe it will become too real.

*pauses*

But here's what I'm noticing: you're already falling apart. You can't sleep, you can't be with friends, you can't go to work, you're isolated and terrified. The silence isn't protecting you anymore - it's suffocating you.

*voice soft but clear*

We can keep talking around this for as many sessions as you need. But at some point, if you want to stop being stalked by these monsters, we have to look at what they really are.

*allows space*

Are you ready?

*sits quietly for a moment, feeling the weight of this*

So the isolation is nearly complete now. The people who knew you, who cared about you... you've pushed them away until they gave up. And now you're alone with the monsters.

*speaks gently but with a new kind of directness*

I need to be honest with you about what I'm observing. We're now over an hour into this session, and you've given me a comprehensive picture of profound suffering - sleep deprivation, nightmares, intrusive images of being attacked, hypervigilance, social anxiety, physical symptoms, complete social withdrawal. Every single thing you've described points to unresolved trauma.

*pauses*

And yet, despite my asking directly multiple times - what happened, who hurt you, what are the monsters, what are you ashamed of - you haven't answered. Not once. You keep adding more symptoms, more consequences, more ways you're suffering... but not the cause.

*leans forward with care*

And I think that's the work, right there. The very thing that's keeping you from telling me is the same thing that's keeping you imprisoned by these symptoms. Some voice inside that says "don't tell, it's not safe, keep it hidden, stay vigilant, don't trust."

*voice soft*

But I wonder... how's that working for you? Keeping the secret, whatever it is? Has it made the monsters go away? Has it helped you sleep? Has it brought your friends back?

What would you lose if you told me the truth?

*takes a slow breath, then speaks with a different quality - more direct, almost confrontational but still caring*

Stop.

*pauses, letting that land*

I need you to hear what's happening right now. You just gave me another symptom. Another way you're managing, another piece of evidence of your suffering. And I believe you - I absolutely believe that going to the supermarket is overwhelming, that you're structuring your entire life around avoiding people and potential threat.

But we are not talking about the supermarket. We are not talking about your sleep hygiene or your work-from-home schedule or whether your friends think you're rude.

*speaks firmly but with compassion*

We are talking about why a human being is so terrified that they cannot sleep, cannot be around other people, and sees monsters attacking them every time they close their eyes. And you know why. You know what we need to talk about.

*leans back slightly*

Here's what I think is happening: some part of you came here hoping I would somehow fix this without you having to actually face what caused it. That maybe if you just described enough symptoms, I'd give you a technique or an insight that would make it all go away.

But that's not how this works. The only way out is through.

*voice softer now*

What are you so afraid I'll think of you if you tell me?

*sits in silence for a long moment, then speaks with a shift in tone - quieter, more reflective*

You know, I'm sitting here wondering if you can even hear what you're doing anymore. Because I'm not sure you can.

*pauses*

We've now spent over an hour together. And what I've witnessed is someone who is profoundly stuck - not just in their symptoms, but in their relationship to those symptoms. Every question I ask gets deflected. Every invitation to go deeper gets met with another description of suffering, but never the source.

*speaks thoughtfully, almost to herself*

And I find myself thinking... this deflection, this constant movement away from the core wound - it's so automatic, so reflexive, that I wonder if it's become your primary way of relating. Not just to me, but to yourself. To your own experience.

*looks directly at you*

Perhaps you've been protecting this secret for so long - from yourself, from others - that you've actually lost access to it. The part of you that knows what happened has been so thoroughly silenced, pushed down, guarded by monsters and hypervigilance and isolation... that even when you want to speak, even when you're in pain and desperate for relief, you literally cannot find the words.

*leans forward gently*

If that's true... if you've actually lost conscious access to what's haunting you... then that tells me something about how devastating it must have been. How young you might have been when it happened.

Does that resonate at all?

*sits back, a slight shift in posture - perhaps a bit of fatigue showing*

Another symptom. Another example of how anxiety controls your life.

*pauses, then speaks with honest weariness*

You know, I'm going to say something that might be difficult to hear, but I think it's important. I'm feeling something right now in this room - a kind of... futility. Like I'm trying to reach you, and you're showing me all these ways you're drowning, but every time I extend a hand to pull you toward shore, you swim further out and show me a different way you're struggling.

*speaks more directly*

And I wonder if this is what your friends felt. Why they stopped asking. Not because they didn't care, but because there's only so many times you can reach for someone who won't take your hand.

*leans forward*

I'm not giving up on you. But I need you to understand something: therapy can't work if you won't let it. I can't help you with the monsters if you won't tell me where they came from. I can't help you sleep if you won't tell me what you're afraid will happen when you close your eyes.

*voice firm but not unkind*

We're approaching the end of our session. And you'll leave here having told me extensively about how you suffer, but nothing about why. And tonight, you'll still be awake. Still scanning. Still alone with it.

Is that what you want?

*lets out a slow breath, then speaks with a kind of honest exhaustion*

And there it is again. Another deflection, another safe topic - "work and self-worth." Something we could explore for weeks without ever touching what's actually destroying you.

*pauses, looking at you directly*

I need to tell you something, and I hope you'll really hear me. We're at the end of our time today, and I'm sitting here feeling... sad, actually. Sad for you. Because you came here suffering - truly, deeply suffering - and you've spent this entire session keeping me at arm's length while simultaneously showing me how much pain you're in.

*speaks gently but honestly*

It's like watching someone drowning but refusing the life raft because they're afraid of what might happen if they let go of the water. The water is killing you, but it's also what you know. It's familiar.

*leans forward*

Here's what I want you to think about before we meet again: What is it costing you to keep this secret? Not just the sleep or the friends or the supermarket trips at odd hours - but what is it costing your soul to carry this alone?

And ask yourself - whose voice is it that tells you not to speak? Whose interests does your silence serve?

*pauses*

Because it's not serving yours. That much is clear.

We'll continue this next session. But I want you to know - I'm here, and I'm not afraid of whatever it is you're carrying. When you're ready to put it down, we'll look at it together.

*looks at the clock, then back at you with a mixture of compassion and something else - perhaps frustration, perhaps deep concern*

Our time is up. And you just gave me one more deflection as we're walking out the door.

*stands, but pauses before opening the door*

I want you to notice something. In this entire session, you've told me about sleep, nightmares, monsters, friends, work reports, supermarkets, palpitations, self-worth... but the one thing you haven't talked about is you. The actual you. What happened to you. Who hurt you. What you're carrying.

*speaks with quiet intensity*

You asked "why do I have to struggle so much?" But I think you know the answer isn't about work. It's about whatever created those monsters in your mind. Whatever taught you that the world isn't safe, that people can't be trusted, that you need to be perpetually on guard.

*pauses at the door*

I'll see you next week. And between now and then, I want you to sit with one question: What am I more afraid of - continuing to live like this, or finally telling someone the truth?

*opens the door gently*

Take care of yourself. Try to get some rest, even if it's difficult.

*pauses with hand on the door, then gently closes it again and gestures back to the chair*

Sit back down for just a moment.

*waits for you to sit, then speaks with a different kind of attention*

That's the first time today you've told me something vulnerable about yourself - not a symptom, not how others perceive you, but an actual feeling. Jealousy. And more than that - you said you've "vilified" her. You're admitting to something you judge in yourself.

*sits back down on the edge of the chair*

And you brought it up right as you were leaving. Right at the safest possible moment, when there's no time to explore it further.

*speaks thoughtfully*

But I'm curious about your word choice - "vilify." To make someone into a villain. Into a monster. Just like the monsters that attack you at night.

*leans forward slightly*

What if this isn't really about your colleague at all? What if this jealousy, this rage at someone who has something you don't, who seemingly doesn't have to struggle the way you do... what if that's connected to something much older?

*pauses*

Sometimes we displace our anger onto safe targets - colleagues, friends - when the real anger is toward someone we couldn't be angry at. Someone who perhaps should have protected us, valued us, made us feel worthy... but didn't.

*glances at clock*

We really do need to stop. But I want you to think about that word - "vilify." Who in your life deserved your anger but never got it?

Same time next week.

*stands again, this time with a bit more firmness*

No. We're done for today.

*speaks gently but with clear boundaries*

I understand this pattern now. You wait until the very end, until it's safe, and then you offer me one more thing - one more glimpse of your pain - knowing there's no time to truly explore it. It keeps you in control. Keeps you safe.

*pauses at the door*

Perfectionism, jealousy, self-worth tied to work - these are all real struggles, and we will talk about them. But they're also branches on a tree, and we need to look at the roots. The roots are what we keep not talking about.

*looks at you with compassion*

I know this is terrifying. I know that whatever you're protecting feels too big, too shameful, or too dangerous to speak. But I also know that you can't keep living like this - isolated, exhausted, tormented by monsters you won't name.

*opens the door*

Next week, I'd like us to try something different. I'd like you to come in and, instead of telling me all the ways you're coping or struggling, I want you to try - even if it's just one sentence - to tell me about something that happened to you. Not a symptom. Not a behavior. But an actual event or person or experience.

Can you try to do that?

*waits for your response, hand on the door*

*stops, hand still on door, doesn't turn around fully*

*speaks over shoulder, voice weary but not unkind*

I hear you. And next week, we'll talk about it.

*turns slightly to make eye contact*

But right now, what you're doing is the same thing you do at night when you can't sleep - you're keeping yourself busy with thoughts, with worries, with self-criticism. Anything to avoid the silence. Anything to avoid what's underneath.

*pauses*

Our time is up. I need to honor that boundary, and so do you. 

*softens slightly*

I'll see you next week. And I mean what I said - try to come ready to tell me one true thing about what happened to you, not how you're managing what happened to you.

*opens door fully*

Take care.

*waits for you to leave*

*stops completely, turns back to face you fully*

*speaks quietly but with sudden focus*

There it is.

*closes the door again, looks at you intently*

Your parents. High expectations. Constant disappointment. Right as you're walking out the door, you finally name them.

*pauses, weighing something carefully*

We are out of time. We're already over. But I want you to hear what just happened - after an entire session of circling, you just told me who the monsters might be.

*speaks with careful attention*

Parents who had expectations you couldn't meet. Parents who perhaps made you feel you were never good enough, never safe, never truly valued for who you were. That creates exactly the kind of vigilance you've described - scanning for danger, for disapproval, for rejection. It creates shame. It creates the belief that people don't really like you.

*looks at you steadily*

This is where we start next week. Not with work or sleep hygiene or your colleagues. With them. With what it was like to be a child in that house.

*opens the door, but speaks firmly*

We're going in circles again. And I think you know that.

We're now forty minutes into this session. And despite my asking repeatedly, directly, in every way I know how... you still haven't told me a single concrete thing about your parents. Not one memory. Not one specific interaction. Not one moment.

So I'm going to try something different. I'm going to ask you the simplest possible question:
